title: Merging a Branch ğŸ”—
ques:
You are on the **`main`** branch and want to incorporate changes from **`feature-login`**.

Run the command to **merge** `feature-login` into your current branch.
explanation: **`git merge <branch>`** combines the history of the specified branch into the current branch.

title: Rebasing a Branch ğŸ—ï¸
ques:
You are working on **`feature-login`** and want to update it with the latest changes from **`main`** by moving your commits to the tip of `main`.

Run the command to **rebase** your current branch onto `main`.
explanation: **`git rebase main`** rewrites your project history by creating new commits for each commit in your original branch, placing them after the last commit of `main`.

title: Aborting a Conflict ğŸ›‘
ques:
You started a merge, but ran into too many conflicts and want to back out.

What command stops the merge and returns the repository to its state before the merge started?
explanation: **`git merge --abort`** stops the merge process and resets the state of the repository to how it was before the merge command was run.

title: Interactive Rebase (Squashing) ğŸ¥
ques:
You have 5 small commits on your branch and want to combine them into a cleaner history before merging.

Start an **interactive rebase** for the last 5 commits.
explanation: **`git rebase -i`** opens an interactive editor where you can squash, fixup, reword, or drop commits to clean up your history.

title: Rebase vs. Merge ğŸ¤”
ques:
You want to integrate changes from `main` into your feature branch **without** creating an extra merge commit, keeping a **linear history**.

Which command should you use: `git merge main` or `git rebase main`?
explanation: **Rebasing** creates a linear history by moving your commits on top of the base branch, whereas **merging** preserves the history structure but creates a merge commit.
